claim: If no one's complaining about your price, you're probably priced too low. Most founders underprice due to fear of rejection or inability to see their product's true value.
rationale: Underpricing forces you to find 10x as many customers and severely limits affordable marketing channels. Higher ARPA unlocks more marketing options—$20/month gives 5 options; $500/month gives 10; $5,000/month gives every approach at your fingertips.

claim: Calculate your plateau number early: Plateau MRR = New MRR / Churn Rate. SaaS plateaus are brutal and difficult to fix, often requiring strategic overhauls.
rationale: If you add $5,000 new MRR monthly with 10% churn, you'll plateau at $50,000 MRR. When new customers equal churning customers, growth stops. Knowing this ceiling early allows proactive intervention before hitting the wall.

claim: Use aspirational pricing: instead of dropping price when customers say 'too expensive,' use feedback to keep improving the tool until it's worth the target price.
rationale: Drip kept $49/month pricing despite early pushback. The founder used complaints as motivation to add value rather than reduce price. This builds a stronger product and avoids the trap of racing to the bottom.

claim: Charge enterprise customers 10-20x your standard plan, not 2-3x. Enterprise deals involve more complexity, procurement hoops, custom integrations, and higher sales costs.
rationale: Underpricing enterprise makes selling to and servicing these accounts unprofitable. If you only charge 2-3x more, you cannot cover the costs of high-touch sales, customer success, and acquisition that enterprise requires.

claim: Churn is the death of SaaS. High churn is hard to outrun and creates brutal plateaus. View aggregate churn as unhelpful—segment by pricing tier, channel, and cohort for actionable insight.
rationale: A product with 2.5 stars from 1,000 reviews might be mediocre, but 500 five-star and 500 one-star reveals half love it and half are wrong fit. Segmenting reveals which customers thrive versus which segments to stop pursuing.

claim: Technical founders who keep coding hamper growth. Coding requires 'Maker's Schedule' (uninterrupted blocks) while founders need 'Manager's Schedule' (one-hour increments for meetings and decisions).
rationale: If coding is comfortable, founders try to solve all business problems (plateaued revenue, high churn, low sales) by building more features, which is often not the real solution. Start hiring developers to free yourself from day-to-day coding.

claim: Don't torch your cap table by letting early investors or cofounders take too much equity. Founders owning only 30-40% after early rounds makes companies uninvestable for future funding.
rationale: Examples include giving 70% to an agency or 60% for a $50k investment. TinySeed declined companies where early leavers still owned large stakes. Investors want founders to own 80-90% after initial rounds.

claim: A lack of money isn't what kills businesses—founder burnout is. Bearing the burden of all unassigned tasks (legal, HR, payroll, operations) while prioritizing customer-facing hires leads to severe burnout.
rationale: Walling experienced listlessness, unmotivation, and constant frustration at Drip despite success. He now considers not hiring an operations manager 'one of the biggest mistakes.' Frontline support especially is a common burnout source.

claim: Dual Funnel Cheat Code: target both wide low-price audience and premium enterprise audience. Low-touch funnel builds brand via word-of-mouth that feeds the high-touch, high-priced funnel.
rationale: Early days, low-touch drives most revenue. As user base grows and high-end users are acquired, enterprise becomes larger percentage of total revenue. SignWell serves professionals needing few signatures and mortgage brokers needing thousands.

claim: Net Negative Churn Cheat Code: expansion revenue outpaces revenue lost from churning customers. Business grows even without new customers; upselling existing customers is much cheaper than acquiring new ones.
rationale: If +4% churn means losing 4% MRR, -4% churn means gaining 4% additional MRR monthly without new customers. Requires getting gross churn to 0-3% range plus driving expansion revenue through value metrics or feature gating.

claim: Compete against large entrenched players by using their strengths against them: undercut on price, offer no-touch sales versus mandatory demos, or build modern UX against legacy codebases.
rationale: Large incumbents are often slow to react, have dated UX, and legacy code. A segment of their user base is frustrated. Target frustrated users wanting to migrate—successfully moving them generates powerful word-of-mouth.

claim: Unique features are a False Moat—they last only a few months until competitors duplicate them. True moats are integrations (network effect), strong brand, owned traffic channels, and high switching costs.
rationale: Relying solely on constant new features creates a 'hamster wheel of features' rather than enduring defense. Zapier's 3,000+ integrations including non-public APIs are nearly impossible to replicate. True moats sustain and grow stronger with the business.

claim: Gymdesk increased prices by over 50% after six years of underpricing, grandfathered old customers briefly, saw only a few of 600+ leave, MRR increased 25%, growth increased 70%.
rationale: Founder Eran Galperin moved old customers to discounted plan after grace period. Customers responded positively saying 'Congrats, you deserve a raise.' Revenue increase enabled hiring four full-time team members.

claim: Drip competed against Infusionsoft by offering free trial versus multi-thousand-dollar setup fees, transparent pricing versus obscured pricing, and no mandatory training. Won frustrated customers seeking simpler buying.
rationale: Used headline 'Lightweight Marketing Automation That Doesn't Suck' to directly contrast with larger, clunkier competitors like Infusionsoft, Marketo, and Pardot. Positioned as scrappy underdog and gained market share.

claim: Gather pivoted from small price-sensitive architect shops at $29/month to larger firms, spent 18 months building features, eventually charged 10x original price while shedding lower-end customers.
rationale: Required painful feature building period but allowed them to double prices, then double again. Moving upmarket meant higher-value customers justified the development investment and created sustainable business.
